L1.brief_rationale: The broadest term for the study of valid reasoning; universally recognized as a field of inquiry.
A set of premises offered in support of a conclusion; foundational vocabulary used in everyday speech and basic philosophy courses.
Reasoning from general principles to specific conclusions; widely taught from secondary school onward.
Reasoning from specific observations to general conclusions; universally familiar as the basis of empirical thinking.
A statement offered as support for a conclusion; basic vocabulary of any introductory logic or philosophy course.
The statement that an argument seeks to establish; universally understood in the context of reasoning.
A seemingly self-contradictory statement that may nonetheless be true; widely recognized through famous examples like the liar paradox.
An error in reasoning that undermines the logical validity of an argument; widely taught in critical thinking and introductory logic.
The property of an argument whose conclusion follows necessarily from its premises; core vocabulary of introductory logic.
A statement that is necessarily false or a pair of statements that cannot both be true; universally understood.
The logical operation that reverses the truth value of a statement; encountered in everyday language and basic mathematics.
A comparison between two things to highlight a shared structure; universally recognized as a reasoning tool.
The process of deriving conclusions from premises or evidence; basic vocabulary of reasoning familiar to all educated people.

L2.brief_rationale: The inference rule affirming the antecedent (if P then Q; P; therefore Q); standard vocabulary for students who have taken introductory logic.
The inference rule denying the consequent (if P then Q; not Q; therefore not P); standard introductory logic content alongside modus ponens.
A form of deductive reasoning with two premises and a conclusion, classically studied since Aristotle; known to students of logic or classical philosophy.
A tabular representation of all possible truth-value combinations for logical connectives; standard tool in introductory logic courses.
The branch of logic dealing with propositions and their connectives (and, or, not, if-then); covered in every introductory logic course.
Logic extended with quantifiers and predicates over individuals; standard second step in undergraduate logic education.
The logical symbols for 'for all' and 'there exists'; introduced in standard undergraduate logic courses.
A formula that is true under every possible interpretation; standard vocabulary in propositional logic courses.
Operators such as conjunction, disjunction, and implication that combine propositions; fundamental to any logic curriculum.
The study of collections of objects forming the foundation of mathematics; known to students who have taken discrete math or foundations courses.
A method of proving a statement by assuming its negation and deriving a contradiction; standard technique taught in undergraduate mathematics and logic.
The property of a valid argument with all true premises; paired with validity as core vocabulary in introductory logic.
The 'if and only if' connective expressing mutual implication; standard vocabulary in propositional logic courses.

L3.brief_rationale: Gödel's result that every logically valid first-order formula is provable; understanding its implications requires working knowledge of model theory and proof theory.
The logic of necessity and possibility using operators like box and diamond; requires working knowledge of Kripke semantics and accessibility relations.
Possible-worlds semantics for modal and intuitionistic logics; requires working knowledge of relational frame structures and truth conditions.
A proof system using introduction and elimination rules for each connective; requires working knowledge of formal proof construction.
Logic permitting quantification over predicates and relations; understanding its expressive power versus first-order logic requires substantial logical training.
A constructive logic rejecting the law of excluded middle; requires working knowledge of constructivism and its philosophical motivations.
An inference rule for automated theorem proving used in logic programming; requires working knowledge of clause normal form and unification.
The result that any satisfiable first-order theory has models of all infinite cardinalities; requires working knowledge of model theory.
If every finite subset of a set of first-order sentences has a model, the whole set does; requires working knowledge of model theory and its applications.
The isomorphism between proofs and programs, types and propositions; requires working knowledge of type theory and proof theory.
Whether there exists an algorithm to determine truth of all sentences in a theory; requires working knowledge of computability theory and its connections to logic.
A set of axioms from which theorems are derived; understanding consistency, independence, and completeness requires working knowledge of formal logic.

L4.brief_rationale: The result that a sufficiently strong consistent system cannot prove its own consistency; understanding its proof via Gödel numbering and the provability predicate requires expert-level knowledge.
Cohen's technique for constructing set-theoretic models to prove independence results; requires expert knowledge of set theory, Boolean-valued models, and generic filters.
Axioms asserting the existence of cardinals with strong combinatorial or reflection properties beyond ZFC; requires deep expertise in set theory and consistency strength hierarchies.
Measuring the proof-theoretic strength of formal systems by assigning ordinals; requires deep expertise in proof theory, ordinal notation systems, and cut-elimination.
Determining which set-existence axioms are necessary and sufficient to prove theorems of ordinary mathematics; requires expert knowledge of subsystems of second-order arithmetic.
Girard's resource-sensitive logic tracking the use of hypotheses; requires deep knowledge of proof nets, cut-elimination, and connections to concurrency theory.
A logic that tolerates contradictions without explosion; requires expert knowledge of relevance logic, dialethism, and non-classical consequence relations.
Modal logic GL axiomatizing the behavior of the formal provability predicate in Peano arithmetic; requires expert knowledge of modal logic and Löb's theorem.
The study of definable subsets of Polish spaces and their complexity via the Borel and projective hierarchies; requires deep expertise in set theory and topology.
Categorical generalization of set theory providing models of constructive mathematics; requires deep expertise in category theory and categorical logic.
A foundational result reducing first-order provability to propositional satisfiability via Herbrand universes; requires expert knowledge of proof theory and automated reasoning.
A stronger consistency condition than simple consistency used in Gödel's original incompleteness argument; requires expert-level understanding of arithmetic and the syntactic form of Gödel sentences.
